api-ref/source/parameters.yaml.message: So don't we usually mark a parameter as required: false if it's optionally not going to show up in the response body dict? If so, shouldn't this and the user_id/project_id ones below also be required: false? I know it's a bit weird semantically since it's based on some internal state stuff rather than, for example, a microversion, but technically they are "optional" in the response regardless of using 1.28+.

Yeah that's the weird semantics I was talking about, but that's the case for things that don't get returned in certain situations, meaning the caller has to be aware the key might not be in the response dict. Anyway, I think that's what we do in nova, e.g. the 'servers' response parameter for GET /os-hypervisors:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=show-hypervisor-details-detail#show-hypervisor-details

It's definitely more confusing in a response parameter than a request parameter, and looking at placement API references where required=false I only see it used in request parameters so I won't rock the boat.

I actually tried that and took it out because with required:false the table cell gets "(Optional)" added, which IMO reads weird, whereas with required:true it's undecorated. If in the latter case it showed e.g. "(Required)" I would agree it should be the other way around.

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: Why is this removed? Is there a case where this condition is True because both are empty?

From the bug report somehow the online data migration resulted in two 'default' legacy security group records being created for project_id=NULL (bc of anonymous get_admin_context) and when queried here, two results were returned instead of the expected single result, causing this comparison to fail and the ironic reaching of "# Not Reached" and a TypeError when this method returned None instead of a list of models.

From code inspection, I could *not* find how a single online data migration created two 'default' legacy security groups with project_id=NULL, so I will need to do some local testing with devstack to figure that out. From the recreates described on the bug, the second duplicate security group is created from the first run of the online data migration, and it doesn't make sense bc the code is supposed to do a "get and if not exist, create". So I don't yet understand how a duplicate gets created.

Update: I investigated this and found (tl;dr) that two 'default' security groups with project_id=NULL get created because we create 'default' group in a separate database transaction (using the 'independent' oslo.db decorator) and a subsequent call to 'get' the 'default' group back (in the instance_create method) will not "see" the group that was created earlier in the instance_create method because of it.

I have proposed a different fix here to use the same 'get or create' method to 'get' the group in order to similarly use a separate transaction for getting it as was used to create it. This way, the 'get' will use a fresh view of the database and see the existing record, and not create a duplicate:

https://review.opendev.org/688206
And then this is None and we blow up below?

Note that a different workaround for this bug had been proposed before in this past:

https://review.opendev.org/653065
So the bug is that _security_group_get_by_names returns None here, correct?

taskflow/conductors/backends/impl_execut.message: Why did you decide to combine the two exception types in this case, instead of leaving them as their own exception paths with clear logging that indicates the state of the job?
Could do that, but thats the current state of the world, this patch was just trying to change the concurrent dispatch limiting mechanism, not this part.
Why did you decide to separate the submission of the job from attempting to claim it? It feels like putting the two together would simplify this logic.
Avoids wasting executor threads on jobs that aren't going to be used in the first place; central claim then dispatch seems simpler imho, but maybe thats just my style, either could be done of course.
Was self._limiter.release() left out on purpose?
See next patch, this changed so that its more obvious whats happening here, but yes, acquire didn't work out, so no release needed.
Right, that shouldn't be possible, hopefully the followup where a exception is raised for this case now makes that more obvious.
Ok, cool. I was thinking along the lines of the self._limiter.acquire() call succeeding at this point, but there not being a release once the submission completed.

So I can see that you are iterating through the jobs on the job board, but the lambda expression seems a little odd to me since is_stopped is not making use of the job parameter. What am I missing here?
Ok, I was thinking that you were using takewhile that way, so we are in sync. I figured I would just ask instead of assuming, ;') . Thanks for the clarification.

Right, its just use as a iteration control/breaking mechanism.

I can write this as:

  for job in self._jobboard.iterjobs():
     if is_stopped():
        break

Either works, what do u prefer?

This just uses itertools.takewhile to do the same thing (exception that itertools function passes the value in, which we don't care about here); https://docs.python.org/2/library/itertools.html#itertools.takewhile

Would it make sense to wrap the max job integer logic in a _convert* function of some kind? Or, even better, create a _create_limiter function that wraps all of the max job logic and factory callout logic for the limiter?
Sure, will do.
Would a log statement be useful here for tracing job transitions?
Sure.
Would a logging statement be useful here, since the claimed job is about to be dispatched?
Sure.
Super nitpicky, but maybe 'is_not_stopped'.  Reads a lot better inline that way.
works for me.

So, when we exhaust our max_dispatches, we stop this loop, but we then just restart the loop because not_is_stopped is still false.  Should not_is_stopped also check for the limiter being exhausted?  Or is there some piece of the puzzle I'm not seeing?

not really, when we exhaust our max_dispatches the acquire() blocks, the only way it returns false if the semaphore was intertuppted (stopped), which happens via the 'stop(self, timeout=None)' in this class, and that method before interuptting the semaphore stops the self._waiter, so 'itertools.takewhile' will stop that and while not_is_stopped will also stop...

thats the reason why this uses a semaphore (that had to be changed to be interruptible, since the built-in python threading one isn't, and it will block up forever...)

taskflow/utils/threading_utils.py.message: Why did you decide not to use a pass statement here?

The string here makes that not needed :)

This is a weird edge case of python where pass isn't needed since python afaik is thinking the string here is used (although it isn't).

Ok. I am going to ask a dumb question: If the default value for the semaphore is 1 when none is provided by the caller, why would you allow for 0 to be a valid value, since you block until you have a value greater than 0?

Hmm. I see your point, but consider this: If you have a single thread and the semaphore value is explicitly set to 0, then I do not think that thread would ever get a chance to do any work, since the acquire() would block indefinitely , waiting for the value to go to 1, right? I believe this also applies for more than one thread.

Soooo,

Mainly because:

https://docs.python.org/2/library/threading.html#semaphore-objects

    '''
    The optional argument gives the initial value for the internal counter; it
    defaults to 1. If the value given is less than 0, ValueError is raised.
    '''

Just mirroring that behavior here; why they let zero be a valid value idk, ha.

See make_interruptible_semaphore_factory which is why its used (and the associated dummy thread); agreed that allowing zero is weird, but this is just an internal utility, and matches the python semaphore weirdness, usage currently all goes through make_interruptible_semaphore_factory so that seems ok (since that handles the less than or equal to zero case in a manner that works for taskflow).

I still don't see the need to add the "customer" suffix.  All the parameters may be overridden by the customer.  Why would we call out this specific parameter with a special naming?

Hi Matt, keep these two lists (default and customer) is more flexible for system admin than hard-coded "default plugins" into deploy script as docker_registries do. 
in additional, the argues of docker_registry just a string (url), however, argues of plugins can be more complex. for example:
"k8s_plugins_default:
  temp:
    tests:
      temptemp

k8s_plugins_customer:
  intel-gpu-plugin:
    intelgpu=enabled
"
k8s_plugins is a dict, the key is plugin's name and the values is plugin's customer argues which could be passed to the system (for intel-gpu-plugin, the argue is a k8s label required to pass to sysinv).

Protocol selection cannot be this dynamic. If a sensor model is created with one protocol it can't be then monitored with another.

Therefore, the hardware monitor should not be able to switch protocols after it has created a sensor model using a previously selected protocol.

There are only 2 cases where the hardware monitor is permitted to learn what BMC communication it should use.

1. After new fresh provisioning ; not just a
   credentials or ip change.

   Must be a de-provision and then re-provision.
   Not even over a process restart.
   This implies that the hardware monitor needs to
      remember with a tmp file what protocol it
      used to create an existing sensor model and
      to continue to use that model even if maintenance
      indicates a change in /var/run/bmc/<compute>.
    hwmond should only look at the protocol field of
    this file when there is no existing sensor model
    read from sysinv.

2. Over a sensor model relearn where the existing
   model is deleted.

when we decide this?

We're kind of "deciding" via this review.

It's something we've been discussing in meetings/IRC and the ML [1] for the past couple of weeks as a way to let us do a "planning exercise" around spec freeze time to limit the number of blueprints we accept in a cycle.

We still haven't decided how we're going to make those decisions -- but once we do, a Definition-approved/Direction-pending blueprint will either get Direction-approved or deferred out of the release.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/009945.html

How the priorities will be managed and when during the lifecycle ? Only once or iteratively, like we were doing with runways ?

FWIW, I'm all good with an iterative approach like we did in the past that wouldn't refrain us to still review other changes that don't have the blessed "Direction" approval.

In other words, saying "this bp is an upstream priority" is one thing, saying "this other bp is not an upstream priority hence being deferred to another cycle" is way more concerning to me.

OK, then could you please clarify that we *could* use (hint: use the conditional instead of the future tense) those LP fields for *maybe* deferring other BP but we still need to discuss this in another change ?
Done

That's still TBD and I don't want to try to nail it down in this patch. As stated above, the Definition/Direction thing just gives us a mechanism for doing it, however we decide to do it.

(And if we decide not to do any such thing, no harm no foul, we just sync Direction approvals and move on.)
I thought we had a mutual agreement at the last PTG to *not* write this down anyway (even if we respect it).

I'm very reluctant to use the words "obligates".
My manager surely obligates me things to do.
On the other way, I surely try to mange my upstream duties as much as I can (and my manager also acknowledges and recognizes this). But that's not an "obligation", just a free will of myself to help the community.
All things we can discuss in whatever reviews attempt to resolve this todo.
So my spec can't get any liaison, it also doesn't mean there is no chance to be approved? Or actually, it already means no approval and no interesting on my spec implicitly?

> So my spec can't get any liaison, it also doesn't mean there
> is no chance to be approved? 

> if you can't find someone willing to be a liaison, there's
> little chance of your spec being approved.

Perhaps this is the issue that is most concerned as a contributor.

Yes: if you can't find someone willing to be a liaison, there's little chance of your spec being approved.

This is an early warning system. In the past cores would frequently approve a spec that was technically valid but nobody cared about. The code would languish and never get reviewed/merged.

This way, you're more likely to get such an effort shut down early in the process, which is preferable to thinking it's going to get in and going through all the work only to have it fail.
Worth promoting.

Also, if alarm.entity_instance_id is too big, then the "alarm clear" string will be truncated.
